content.title: Built-for-Rent Communities REIT
content.subtitle: Open-ended private REIT investing in Class A BFR single-family communities

content.title: Fund at a Glance
content.subtitle: Perpetual capital platform for institutional-quality BFR communities

metrics.label: Amenities
metrics.value: Class A: pool, clubhouse, fitness, trails, dog park, coworking

content.takeaway: Scale + repeatable community model aims to deliver durable income and growth.

content.title: Investment Highlights
content.takeaway: BFR combines single-family demand with multifamily operating efficiency.
bullets: Housing affordability crisis keeps households renting longer; the monthly cost to own remains meaningfully above renting in many markets
Structural under-supply of homes supports long-term rental demand and limits oversupply risk
Purpose-built communities deliver privacy/space + professional management; potential for higher retention vs traditional multifamily
Dual deployment channels create cycle resilience: acquire stabilized communities from builders or develop ground-up with sponsor partners
Nationwide mandate with disciplined filters: growth, jobs, supply constraints, landlord friendliness, and climate/insurance diligence
Institutional validation: public SFR REITs at scale (AMH, INVH) plus large private capital scaling the category (e.g., Blackstone/Tricon)
content.notes: For discussion purposes only; not an offer to sell or a solicitation.

content.title: Open-Ended Private REIT Structure
content.takeaway: NAV-based subscriptions and periodic liquidity aim to align long-duration housing with investor needs.
left_bullets: Perpetual capital can hold through cycles and capture long-duration housing returns
Diversification across MSAs and construction vintages can smooth cash flows
Potential for regular distributions from stabilized rental income
Operational scale (leasing, maintenance, procurement) can improve margins
right_bullets: NAV-based subscriptions/redemptions (frequency and gates TBD in offering docs)
Independent valuation process and audited financials
Moderate leverage target with liquidity buffers
Non-traded structure may reduce mark-to-market volatility vs public equities
RIA-friendly reporting and investor communications
content.notes: Final terms will be set in definitive offering documents.

content.title: Strategy at a Glance
content.takeaway: A dual-track approach targets both speed-to-income and development alpha.
left_bullets: Acquire new communities directly from homebuilders (single asset or portfolio)
Faster deployment and quicker cash-flow ramp
Potential to buy at or below replacement cost vs scattered retail SFR
Professional lease-up, branding, and operations to drive stabilization
right_bullets: Partner with sponsors for land, entitlements, and execution expertise
Capture development spread and optimize design-to-rent product
Phased deliveries support absorption and reduce lease-up risk
Exit optionality: hold, refinance, bulk sale, or retail disposition
content.notes: Transaction pace and mix will vary by cycle; underwriting includes stress tests.

content.section_subtitle: Affordability + supply constraints are accelerating demand for built-for-rent.

content.title: Mortgage Payment vs Rent: Ownership Premium
content.takeaway: Even before taxes/insurance/maintenance, the monthly payment to buy can be materially higher than rent.
content.notes: Source: CBRE Build-to-Rent Overview 2024 (national; Q2 2024 mortgage payment ~52% above rent).

content.title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Households
content.takeaway: High prices and elevated mortgage rates extend renter tenure and expand the addressable BFR market.
bullets: Home prices increased sharply since early 2020, raising barriers for first-time buyers
Higher mortgage rates meaningfully increased the monthly payment on a median-priced home in 2024
The “lock-in” effect discourages existing owners from selling, limiting for-sale inventory
Many renters prefer the space, schools, and lifestyle of single-family neighborhoods but cannot (or choose not to) buy
Implication: BFR provides a single-family lifestyle without the downpayment and long-term debt commitment
content.notes: Source: Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies (2024/2025 press materials).

content.title: Structural Housing Shortage Supports Rental Demand
content.takeaway: The U.S. is under-housed—supporting long-term occupancy and rent growth for well-located rental homes.
bullets: National housing supply is structurally constrained after a decade-plus of underbuilding
Shortage estimates remain in the millions of units, especially in starter homes and affordable segments
New construction is challenged by land, labor, materials, and financing costs
Even with elevated multifamily deliveries in some metros, single-family demand remains resilient
Implication: new, professionally managed rental supply can be absorbed in growth markets with the right submarket selection
content.notes: Source: Freddie Mac housing supply gap analysis (Nov 2024).

content.title: BTR Completions Have Scaled Rapidly
content.takeaway: Purpose-built single-family rental supply is growing—but remains small vs overall housing needs.
content.notes: Source: Yardi Matrix via Point2Homes (Apr 2025). 2024 completions 39,000 (+15.5% vs 2023); pre-pandemic ~6–7k/yr.

content.title: BTR Pipeline Is Large—But the Sector Is Still Early
content.takeaway: Near-term deliveries are meaningful, yet BTR remains a small slice of the U.S. housing stock.
bullets: ≈110k BTR homes are underway nationally across development stages (as of Mar 2025)
National BTR inventory is ~350k units (~1.5% of ~23M U.S. single-family rentals)
Institutional ownership of SFR remains low (often cited <2%), leaving a fragmented competitive landscape
Supply growth is constrained by the same factors affecting all housing: land, labor, materials, and financing
Implication: scale operators with capital access and repeatable models can grow into an under-institutionalized asset class
content.notes: Sources: Point2Homes/Yardi Matrix (pipeline) and CBRE Build-to-Rent Overview 2024 (inventory; ownership context).

content.title: Top BTR Metros by 2024 Completions
content.takeaway: BTR supply is concentrated in high-growth metros—creating programmatic scale opportunities.
content.notes: Source: Point2Homes (Apr 2025) using Yardi Matrix data.

content.title: Demand Is Broad-Based and Demographically Driven
content.takeaway: BFR demand spans life stages—improving resiliency versus single-tenant segments.
bullets: Millennials forming families want space, storage, and school access but face affordability constraints
Baby Boomers value downsizing, low-maintenance living, and flexibility for relocation/caregiving
Remote/hybrid work increases the value of extra rooms, garages, and outdoor space
High-income renters by choice prioritize mobility and service over ownership responsibilities
Families seek suburban neighborhood quality with professional management and predictable costs
content.notes: Demographic demand themes reflected across CBRE, Point2Homes, and public SFR REIT commentary.

content.section_title: BFR Product: Class A Horizontal Living
content.section_subtitle: Townhomes, detached and cottage-style homes in amenity-rich communities.

content.title: What We Build / Buy
content.takeaway: Purpose-built design enables scale operations and a consistent resident experience.
bullets: 100–200-home, professionally managed communities (horizontal multifamily operating model)
Mix of detached homes, townhomes, and cottage-style product to optimize density and affordability
Private outdoor space (yard/patio), garages/driveways, and durable finishes
Central amenity core supports resident experience and retention
Standardized plans simplify maintenance and reduce lifecycle CapEx volatility
Community design creates “retail-like” buyer optionality at exit (sell homes individually or in bulk)
content.notes: BTR community characteristics and density ranges described in CBRE research.

content.title: Unit Typologies & Design Principles
content.takeaway: A blended unit mix expands the renter pool while optimizing land use and achievable rents.
left_bullets: Efficient land use and infrastructure cost per unit
Private entries + patios/yards with strong community feel
Typically 2–3 bedrooms; fits young families and downsizers
Supports moderate rents with Class A finishes
right_bullets: 3–4 bedrooms and larger yards for family demand
Higher rent point with strong retention potential
Garages/driveways and storage support suburban lifestyle
Phased delivery aligns supply with absorption
content.notes: Final unit mix will be market- and site-specific.

content.title: Class A Amenity Stack
content.takeaway: Amenities create a differentiated lifestyle and support pricing power.
bullets: Resort-style pool + clubhouse / community kitchen
Fitness studio, trails, greenspace, and outdoor gathering areas
Dog park + pet wash; playgrounds and flexible open space
Coworking / work-from-home spaces and package lockers
On-site leasing and maintenance with service-level targets
Community programming to build belonging and reduce churn
content.notes: Amenity package tailored to local demographics and competitive set.

content.title: BFR Can Command a Rent Premium vs Apartments
content.takeaway: Rent premiums and retention are core drivers of BFR NOI growth.
bullets: Industry research and operator data frequently cite BTR rent premiums vs traditional multifamily (~10–20%) driven by space and privacy
Premium is supported by unit features: private yards/patios, garages, and no neighbors above/below
Amenity-rich communities attract renters seeking single-family lifestyle with professional management
Lower turnover can reduce vacancy and make-ready costs, improving NOI durability
Design-to-rent durability (standardized finishes) can reduce recurring CapEx volatility
content.notes: Sources include CBRE and industry/operator commentary (e.g., RCLCO; NexMetro).

content.title: SFR Rent Growth Has Outpaced Multifamily
content.takeaway: Over the last decade, single-family rent growth has exceeded multifamily nationally.
content.notes: Source: Houlihan Lokey SFR Market Update (Aug 2025) citing ~5.5% SFR vs ~4.2% multifamily rent CAGR.

content.title: Two Core Resident Personas
content.takeaway: BFR serves both renters-by-necessity and renters-by-choice.
bullets: Millennials: household formation + desire for space; many are constrained by downpayment/mortgage qualification
Boomers: desire for low-maintenance living, flexibility, and “lock-and-leave” convenience
Shared needs: privacy, safety, storage, pet-friendliness, and professional service
BFR offers the benefits of single-family living without maintenance burden and long-term leverage
Community design (fitness, trails, social spaces) supports cross-generational appeal
content.notes: Resident personas commonly cited across industry research and operator disclosures.

content.title: Operating Model = Horizontal Multifamily
content.takeaway: Community operations create cost and service advantages vs scattered SFR.
bullets: On-site leasing and centralized maintenance teams improve service and reduce travel time
Standardized plans drive predictable make-ready costs and consistent unit turns
Smart-home tech (locks, thermostats, sensors) can reduce risk and improve resident satisfaction
Bulk procurement and preferred vendors support margin expansion with scale
Data-driven pricing and renewal optimization support NOI growth
Single-family product typically has fewer shared-wall systems than MF, reducing some repair complexity
content.notes: Operating model tailored by market and property management platform.

content.section_subtitle: Cycle-resilient deployment across acquisition and development channels.

content.title: Sourcing Engine and Capital Deployment
content.takeaway: A programmatic pipeline supports scale-up to a multi-billion-dollar portfolio.
bullets: Direct builder relationships for single-asset and portfolio purchases (takeouts)
Preferred JV partnerships with regional sponsors for land and development execution
Repeatable community template enables faster underwriting and design standardization
Diversify across markets and delivery vintages to smooth lease-up and valuation cycles
Prioritize submarkets with strong household formation and limited competitive supply
Target communities sized for both operating scale and absorption velocity
content.notes: Execution plan balances pace of deployment with underwriting discipline.

content.title: Deal Sourcing: Two Complementary Channels
content.takeaway: Builder takeouts accelerate deployment while JV development captures spread and product control.
left_bullets: Acquire finished or near-finished communities directly from builders
Immediate leasing platform and reduced construction risk
Structured forward commitments can secure pipeline and pricing
Potential for volume pricing relative to scattered retail acquisitions
right_bullets: Partner with experienced sponsors for entitlements and build execution
Capture development economics and tailor product/amenities to renters
Phased completion reduces absorption and carry risk
Flexible exit strategies (hold, refinance, bulk or retail sale)
content.notes: Channel mix will reflect market conditions and relative risk-adjusted returns.

content.title: Underwriting Discipline and Downside Protection
content.takeaway: Underwriting prioritizes durability and capital preservation across cycles.
bullets: Target basis at or below replacement cost where feasible; focus on new, low-CapEx product
Stress test interest rates, lease-up timing, rent growth, and insurance costs
Preference for fixed-rate or hedged debt; ladder maturities and maintain liquidity buffers
Phased delivery and pre-leasing to reduce lease-up volatility
CapEx reserves and proactive maintenance reduce headline risk and improve resident satisfaction
Exit optionality provides additional downside protection
content.notes: Investment decisions governed by IC process and portfolio-level risk limits.

content.title: Target Underwriting Parameters (Illustrative)
content.takeaway: Standardized targets support repeatability while allowing market-specific adjustments.
rows: Amenity ROI + operating scale; manageable absorption
Aligned with large-scale SFR operator benchmarks
Supports distributable cash flow and cap rate buffer
Moderate leverage to protect NAV across cycles
content.notes: Illustrative targets; actual underwriting varies by market, timing, and asset channel.

content.title: Lease-Up and Stabilization Playbook
content.takeaway: Execution focus shortens time to stabilized cash flow.
bullets: Pre-marketing during construction (virtual tours, waitlists, broker outreach)
Staggered home deliveries to maintain leasing momentum and reduce vacancy clusters
Dynamic pricing by floorplan and finish package; renewal optimization to protect retention
Amenity activation early (clubhouse, trails, dog park) to accelerate absorption
Focus on resident experience KPIs: response time, satisfaction, renewal rate, delinquency
Local market intelligence loops into pricing, concessions, and staffing
content.notes: Lease-up approach is market-specific and informed by real-time comps.

content.title: Public Benchmarks: AMH & INVH Operating Metrics
content.takeaway: Large-scale operators demonstrate high occupancy and steady rent growth through cycles.
rows: Avg length of stay ~38 months; ~80% renewal rate in Q4 2024
content.notes: Sources: AMH FY2024 results (Feb 2025) and Invitation Homes FY2024 & Q3 2025 supplemental disclosures.

content.title: Cap Rate Comparison: SFR vs Multifamily (Mar 31, 2025)
content.takeaway: SFR cap rates have traded at a modest premium valuation vs multifamily in some segments.
content.notes: Source: Houlihan Lokey SFR Market Update (Aug 2025); cap rates as of Mar 31, 2025.

content.section_subtitle: Nationwide mandate; disciplined filters to focus on resilient demand and controllable supply.

content.title: Market Selection Framework
content.takeaway: Consistent filters allow investing across primary and secondary MSAs while protecting downside.
bullets: Household formation and job growth supported by diversified employers
Affordability gap between owning and renting supports sustained rental demand
Favorable supply/demand dynamics: limited new home inventory or zoning/land constraints
Landlord-friendly legal environment and predictable property taxes
Climate and insurance diligence to avoid outsized tail risk (or price for it)
Depth of builder activity and local development pipeline for programmatic sourcing
content.notes: Framework is applied at both MSA and submarket levels.

content.title: Primary vs Secondary MSA Approach
content.takeaway: A blended market strategy balances liquidity with yield and growth potential.
left_bullets: Deeper liquidity and buyer depth for bulk exits
Diverse employment bases and household formation engines
Ability to scale multiple communities within a single metro
Institutional-quality submarkets with strong school districts
right_bullets: Potentially higher yields and development spreads
Lower competition for land and approvals in select corridors
Fast-growing pockets anchored by universities, healthcare, and manufacturing
Opportunity to be early institutional operator with brand advantage
content.notes: Portfolio mix will be actively managed based on risk-adjusted opportunity.

content.title: Example Target MSAs (Illustrative)
content.takeaway: Focus on metros combining household growth, affordability demand, and BTR momentum.
rows: High in-migration; strong household growth; favorable suburban land availability
Large job base and affordability-driven renters; deep builder ecosystem
Job growth + household formation; strong SFR culture
Scale + affordability relative to other primaries; deep workforce demand
In-migration + white-collar growth; strong suburban submarkets
Migration + constrained ownership affordability; high demand for space
Affordable coastal Sun Belt metro; strong family renter demand
Midwest growth node; stable employment and lower supply pressure
High-income renter base; strong lifestyle demand; supply requires submarket discipline
Affordable large metro with strong renter pool and land availability
content.notes: Source: Point2Homes (Apr 2025) for completions and pipeline stats where stated; remaining entries illustrative.

content.title: Submarket and Site Selection Criteria
content.takeaway: Submarket discipline protects lease-up velocity and long-term liquidity.
bullets: Proximity to employment nodes, retail convenience, and strong school districts
Commute and access: major road connectivity; avoid long-term infrastructure gaps
Parcel size supports 100–200 homes plus meaningful greenspace and amenity core
Entitlements that allow horizontal density appropriate to product (often ~6–12 units/acre)
Construction feasibility: standardized plans, phased infrastructure, utility access
Competition mapping: quantify MF deliveries, BTR pipeline, and rent positioning by submarket
content.notes: Site criteria tailored to local zoning and market comps.

content.section_subtitle: Public REIT benchmarks, private operators, and our competitive edge.

content.title: Competitive Landscape Snapshot
content.takeaway: The sector has proven scalability, but institutional-quality BFR communities remain under-supplied.
bullets: Public comps: AMH and INVH operate large-scale SFR portfolios with high occupancy and steady NOI growth
Private capital continues to scale: Blackstone acquired Tricon Residential and highlighted a sizable development pipeline
Horizontal multifamily operators validate cottage/townhome formats with amenity-driven demand
Most SFR remains owned by small landlords; institutional ownership remains relatively low
Opportunity: deliver consistent resident experience through purpose-built communities and professional operations
content.notes: Sources: public REIT disclosures; Blackstone/Tricon press releases; CBRE market commentary.

content.title: Our Competitive Edge
content.takeaway: BFR sits at the intersection of SFR demand and multifamily efficiency.
left_bullets: On-site teams reduce maintenance response times and travel costs
Amenities + branding support pricing power and faster lease-up
Standardized homes reduce make-ready variability and CapEx surprises
Concentrated communities improve data quality for pricing and renewals
Community design supports safety and resident satisfaction
right_bullets: Greater privacy: no neighbors above/below and more space
Garages/yards support families, pets, and hybrid work
Suburban school districts and neighborhood feel
Retention tends to be higher; turnover costs lower
Often competitively priced vs the cost of buying
content.notes: Relative advantages vary by market and competitive set.

content.title: Institutional Validation + Whitespace
content.takeaway: Institutional momentum is rising, but sector penetration remains low—creating opportunity.
bullets: Large transactions (e.g., Blackstone/Tricon) signal conviction in the long-term SFR/BTR thesis
BTR remains a small fraction of the U.S. housing stock—leaving room for institutional growth
BTR starts and completions have increased as builders respond to affordability-driven demand
Long runway: even modest increases in BTR’s share of new single-family construction creates meaningful scale
Our REIT targets that whitespace through programmatic acquisition and development relationships
content.notes: Sources: Blackstone/Tricon press releases; NAHB built-for-rent starts analysis; CBRE BTR overview.

content.section_subtitle: Target ~12% net return supported by income, growth, and disciplined risk management.

content.title: How We Aim to Deliver ~12% Net Return
content.takeaway: Returns are designed to be driven primarily by income and NOI growth, not cap-rate bets.
bullets: Current income from stabilized rental cash flow (net of expenses, reserves, and leverage costs)
Organic NOI growth from rent increases, lease-up, and renewal optimization
Development/acquisition alpha via programmatic sourcing and design standardization
Potential appreciation supported by long-term housing scarcity and home price floor dynamics
Exit optionality (bulk, retail, refinance) can protect downside and create upside
content.notes: Targets are not guaranteed; performance depends on market conditions and execution.

content.title: Illustrative Total Return Drivers (Net, Annualized)
content.takeaway: Income + NOI growth are expected to be the largest contributors.
content.notes: Illustrative only; not a forecast.

content.title: Liquidity Management for an Open-Ended REIT
content.takeaway: Structure is designed to provide periodic liquidity while protecting remaining investors.
bullets: Staggered community vintages create recurring stabilization events and cash-flow growth
Maintain liquidity buffer (cash + credit) to fund redemptions and CapEx needs
Moderate leverage and laddered maturities reduce refinancing concentration risk
Redemption program balances investor liquidity with long-duration assets (gates may apply)
Regular third-party valuation supports transparent NAV reporting
content.notes: Illustrative structure; final details set in offering documents.

content.title: Key Risks and Mitigations
content.takeaway: Risks are identifiable and manageable with disciplined underwriting and operations.
rows: Moderate leverage; fixed/hedged debt; conservative entry yields; liquidity buffers
GMP contracts where possible; experienced sponsor partners; contingency; phased deliveries
Submarket discipline; pre-leasing; dynamic pricing; amenity activation; staffing plan
Restrictions on investor ownership or rent regulation in select areas
Jurisdiction selection; compliance programs; proactive resident experience and transparency
Climate diligence; diversify geography; higher deductibles/risk pools; resilient construction standards
Near-term rent pressure in certain submarkets
Avoid high-supply corridors; pipeline monitoring; differentiate via product/amenities; maintain pricing discipline
content.notes: Policy discussion context includes research from the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis (Mar 2024) and broader market commentary.

content.title: Capital Raise Plan & Next Steps
content.takeaway: We are building a scalable platform to meet demand for high-quality rental housing.
bullets: Target raise: $2–3B to build a diversified, multi-market BFR portfolio
Pipeline: builder takeout opportunities plus curated JV sponsor relationships
Phased deployment: seed portfolio → scale to programmatic acquisitions → optimize operations
Investor diligence package: market research, underwriting framework, and case studies
Next steps: diligence meetings with RIAs, model portfolio fit assessment, and onboarding workflow
content.notes: Investment offered only via definitive offering documents.
